result_comments: Freedom of Information policies for Climate Finance Funds were scored as follows. If the Fund has its own policy, this was scored in line with our FOIA scoring for DFI and IFI. If the Fund uses the policies of other donors, given that many climate funds work in close collaboration with other IFIs, the climate fund must make specific reference to those policies, so that someone seeking to make a freedom of information request would be guided to the correct institution. Then, we will assign the score of that institution to the climate fund.   Scoring as follows:  (1): No policy, no reference to relevant policies  (2-4)- Policy exists, or clear reference to the relevant policy is made.   The Adaptation Fund does not have its own policy, and no information refferring to relevant policies at other institutions could be found.
The Adaptation Fund operates under the authority of the Conference of the Parties of the UNFCCC. Its funding strategy is set by decisions made by the COP
result_review: AdaptationFund  PeerReviewer: The assessment is correct. It is more accurate to say, though, that the Adaptation Fund Board operates under the authority of the Conference of the Parties of the UNFCCC serving as the Meeting of Parties of the Kyoto Protocol (CMP).

result_comments: The Adaptation fund has not yet published an annual report.
result_review: AdaptationFund  PeerReviewer: The assessment is incorrect. The first annual performance report of the AF was published in December 2011 and is available at http://www.adaptation-fund.org/sites/default/files/AFB.EFC_.7.4.Rev_.2%20Annual%20Performance%20Report.pdf.  By Board decision, such reports will be published annually, and will be made available on the website, so the rating should be set to 4: Yes, the donor always publishes the latest version of this document.  - Agree with donor comments, changed to a 4- JA from Publish

result_comments: The Adaptation Fund is still defining allocation policy
result_review: AdaptationFund  PeerReviewer: The assessment is incorrect. The Operational Policies and Guidelines states (paragraph 26) that â€œa cap in resource allocation per eligible host country, project and programme will be agreed by the Board based on a periodic assessment of the overall status of resources in the Adaptation Fund Trust Fund and with a view to ensuring equitable distributionâ€ (http://www.adaptation-fund.org/sites/default/files/OPG%20Revised%204.4.12%20(with%20annexes).pdf). The Board has made an active decision based on the mentioned document, in its 13th meeting (March 2011), to â€œApprove a cap of US $10 million for each country funded for support by the Adaptation Fundâ€ (Decision B.13/23, available at http://www.adaptation-fund.org/sites/default/files/AFB13%20Final%20Report_0.pdf). Therefore the policy, albeit very simple, is published, and the rating should be set to 4: Yes, it is always published.  - Agree that it should be a 4, but based specifically on article 16 of this document: http://adaptation-fund.org/system/files/file/AFB_Operational%20Policies%20and%20Guidelines.pdf - JA from Publish

AdaptationFund  PeerReviewer: The assessment is correct. The main source of revenue of the Adaptation Fund, the monetization of the Certified Emission Reductions (CERs) is unpredictable, because it depends on several factors at play at the global level, such as the international climate negotiations and the price of carbon (which in turn depends on e.g. global macroeconomic trends). Because the expected revenue is unknown, budgeting for three years is also practically impossible.

AdaptationFund  PeerReviewer: The assessment is correct. Because the project funding in the AF is not based on preset allocations but on a country-specific cap (cf. Question 3) and approval of proposals on a rolling basis, there are no country-specific forward planned budgets, apart from disbursement plans for already approved projects.

If, as in Question 6 above, procurement refers to procurement within projects financed by the AF and implemented by NIEs, RIEs and MIEs, the annual project performance reports (PPRs) of the AF are required to provide procurement information for all contracts over US$2,500 (http://www.adaptation-fund.org/sites/default/files/AFB.EFC_.9.4.Add_.1%20Draft%20Guidance%20to%20Complete%20PPRs.pdf). However, due to the sensitive information contained in that section (including bid amounts and winning bids) the section will not be made public. Therefore, the correct rating would be 2: No, the donor does not publish this, but it does collect it.  - Changed to a 2 based on donor comments- JA from Publish

result_comments: The adaptation fund has not yet published an annual audit
result_review: AdaptationFund  PeerReviewer: The projects are not required to submit annual audits, only a final audit of their financial statements. However, the World Bank yearly issues the World Bank Groupâ€™s management assertion regarding the effectiveness of internal controls over financial reporting of modified cash basis trust funds (Single Audit report), the latest being for the year ended June 2011. The Single Audit provides an annual assessment of the overall control framework surrounding the preparation of financial reports for modified cash basis trust funds administered by the World Bank.  The Single Audit report can be accessed via the Bank's website at the following address: http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/EXTABOUTUS/0,,contentMDK:22669594~pagePK:51123644~piPK:329829~theSitePK:29708,00.html

result_comments: The Adaptation fund does not publish country strategy papers. It accredits national implementing entities to develop country strategies.
result_review: AdaptationFund  PeerReviewer: The assessment is correct but the question is not applicable. The Adaptation Fund does not have country specific strategy papers, because the Fund is based on the principle of country-drivenness, and its Strategic Priorities, Policies and Guidelines adopted by the CMP state that â€œin assessing project and programme proposals, the Adaptation Fund Board shall give particular attention to: a) Consistency with national sustainable development strategies, including, where appropriate, national development plans, poverty reduction strategies, national communications and national adaptation programmes of action and other relevant instruments, where they exist [â€¦]â€ (http://www.adaptation-fund.org/sites/default/files/OPG%20Revised%204.4.12%20%28with%20annexes%29.pdf, Annex 1). Accordingly, the project proposal review criteria have a specific question on consistency with the above national strategies (same document, Annex 3). As those strategies are not immaterial property of the Adaptation Fund, they are not published on the AF website. However, the most relevant of them, the National Adaptation Programmes of Action (NAPAs) which are developed in the UNFCCC framework for the Least Developed Countries are available on the UNFCCC website (http://unfccc.int/cooperation_support/least_developed_countries_portal/items/4751.php). Further, the NIE are not accredited to develop country strategies but to implement projects funded by the AF.   - You could argue that this question is either not applicable for the reasons set out above, or they score a '4', as country strategies are published in the project documents- in their applications, the proposed projects are systematically placed in the context of a national sustainable development strategy- have scored a 4 for this reason- JA from Publish

result_comments: The adaptation fund does not set country budgets.
result_review: AdaptationFund  PeerReviewer: The assessment is not totally correct. All eligible countries (Non-Annex I Parties of the UNFCCC that are Parties to the Kyoto Protocol) are subject to the same interim cap of US$ 10 million per country. That US$10 million is not an entitlement but a cap on proposals that are assessed on a rolling basis, and therefore there are not forward planning budgets per country. Each approved project, however, contains a disbursement schedule showing annual tranches. In that sense, forward planning budget exists in the format mentioned but is not published separately on the website. It is part of the project document.  - Agreed, would change to 4 as all projects have annual tranches for disbursements- as there is only one project per country, the total spend at the country level is a given with the published project documents- JA from Publish

result_comments: Model agreements with National Implementing Entities, and Grantees are published, but not actual agreements.
result_review: AdaptationFund  PeerReviewer: The assessment appears is not totally correct. As this section of the index deals with the country level i.e. relationship between the AF and countries, the question here should refer to any framework MoU between the Fund and the country, and not project-specific agreements (activity level). There are no framework MoUs in the AF, and only after project approval a project-specific legal agreement is prepared, which is dealt with at Question 39 below. To provide the overarching regulatory framework, instead of a country MoU, the project agreement includes as an annex the version of AF Operational Policies and Guidelines applicable at the time of agreement, and that global document, together with the standard legal agreement governs all issues not explicitly detailed in the project document.   - In this case, the project level contract would also serve the purpose of the MOU, and is collected and not published- JA from Publish

result_review: AdaptationFund  PeerReviewer: Assessment is correct. We could add that funding is based on the full cost of adaptation principle and no co-financing is required (source: Decision 5/CMP.2, OPG, Revised Instructions to Proponents).

result_comments: Funding to the Adaptation Fund is a combination of donor ODA and a levy on the Clean Development Mechanism, therefore it is not divided into climate finance vs ODA. All funding through the Adaptation Fund is likely to be considered as climate finance but this term has not yet been defined by the UNFCCC.
result_review: AdaptationFund  PeerReviewer: Funding to the Adaptation Fund is a combination of donor ODA and a levy on the Clean Development Mechanism, therefore it is not divided into climate finance vs ODA. All funding through the Adaptation Fund is likely to be considered as climate finance but this term has not yet been defined by the UNFCCC. Response: It is not clear whether donor contributions to the AF should be considered ODA as defined by OECD DAC: in ODA the main objective of funding should be economic development and welfare (http://www.oecd.org/document/4/0,3746,en_2649_34447_46181892_1_1_1_1,00.html).  In the AF, the main objective is to address the adverse effects of climate change (Decision 5/CMP.2), and more specifically to a) assist developing country Parties to the Kyoto Protocol that are particularly vulnerable to the adverse effects of climate change in meeting the costs of adaptation and b) finance concrete adaptation projects and programmes that are country driven and are based on the needs, views and priorities of eligible Parties (Strategic Priorities, Policies and Guidelines, in http://www.adaptation-fund.org/sites/default/files/OPG%20Revised%204.4.12%20%28with%20annexes%29.pdf, Annex 1). Funding through the AF may be considered climate finance once that term is defined by the UNFCCC. However, the AF should not be negatively assessed (currently proposed value 1 on a scale from 0 to 4) because of a categorization process that is outside the control of the AF. The AF is absolutely transparent about both the sources and recipients of its funding. Reports are prepared by the trustee for each AFB meeting, most recent is at http://www.adaptation-fund.org/sites/default/files/AFB.EFC_.9.8%20Adaptation%20Fund%20Trust%20Fund%20-%20Financel%20Report.pdf.  Further, many Annex I parties to the UNFCCC did report contributions to the Adaptation Fund in their national communications (e.g. Spain did so in their 5th national communication, page 261 - http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/esp_nc5.pdf), as part of and through their investments in the CDM (the 2% SOP). (Although they did not report the 45 million EUR donation).  Reporting flows under ODA is done by the donor countries and beyond the capacity of the AF. In addition, the OECD Rio Markers are now attempting to track climate finance flows and adaptation was just recently added. A decision similar to Questions 13 and 14 above would be appropriate: as definition of climate finance in relation to ODA has not been set outside of the AF process, AF cannot report on such distinction and the question should not apply.   -

AdaptationFund  PeerReviewer: Assessment is incorrect. Whenever the project proposal draws on an appraisal or earlier study conducted in the country, the results of such assessment are provided in the proposal, and the assessment report is included as an annex of the proposal document and posted online. Earlier some annexes were not posted because they were not considered crucial or because of document size limitations but since early 2012 all proposal related documentation submitted together with the proposal are annexed and posted.  Earlier, project reviews carried out by the secretariat were kept confidential and not posted but starting from the review cycle for AFB18 (April to June 2012) secretariat final review sheets are posted online as part of publicly shared meeting documentation.  - There also appears to be a relatively extensive section of the project document which is comparable to a impact appraisal, have changed to 4 based on this and donor comments. AdaptationFund  PeerReviewer: Assessment is correct but unreasonable considering the AF mode of operations and therefore the proper rating for this criterion would be â€œnot applicableâ€. AF projects are implemented by Multilateral, Regional or National Implementing Entities, which are responsible for project supervision. Their share of the project funds in that role is limited to maximum 8.5% of the total granted project funding. They supervise the activities of executing entities, which can be government agencies, non-governmental organizations or other entities, which are responsible for the main part of the project activities on the ground, and are thus recipients of the major part of project funds. The budget classification of such organizations varies between different countries and even among different types of organizations in a given country. The above criterion would be relevant in cases where funding is granted in a budget support manner to a recipient government but does not suit the variety of AF recipient organizations.

result_evidence: The last strategy document was publisehd in 2005. It is called 'Diretrizes para a CooperaÃ§Ã£o Tecnica Internacional Multilateral e Bilateral'.  http://www.abc.gov.br/documentos/Diretrizes-CTI.pdf
result_comments: As Brazil is a very recent player as a donor, it still doesn't have appropriate tools to work in that field. Government prefers to talk about 'Brazilian Cooperation for International Development' rather than â€œAidâ€. They define the international cooperation as non repayable grants invested in other countries. This definition is more restrictive than the one adopted by OCDE. The Federal government has an agency responsible for the technical cooperation (ABC) but more than 60 federal bodies develop direct cooperation. And another area in Foreign Affairs Ministry is responsible for humanitarian actions called CGFome: http://www.itamaraty.gov.br/o-ministerio/o-ministerio/cgfome-coordenacao-geral-de-acoes-internacionais-de-combate-a-fome/

result_evidence: The Brazilian Agency for Cooperation (ABC) is starting to collect information to publish annual reports. This is done in partnership with IPEA - a research institute linked to Presidency. They published their first report for the period 2005-2009: http://www.abc.gov.br/lerNoticia.asp?id_Noticia=606  The Humanitarian area of FA also published a report for the period 2006-2010. Unfortunately it is not available on their website, only in hard copy: http://cooperacaohumanitaria.itamaraty.gov.br/pt-br/Main.xml  There is also a summary of ABC actions in Africa, which looks similar to an Annual Report, but only from 2010. http://www.abc.gov.br/abc_por/Conteudo/CatalogoABCAfrica2010_I.pdf

If the document exists, it is not publicly available. It is important to stress that ABC doesn't have any debate or involvement of civil society organization in its strategy and plans. FA is not a very open Ministry, compared to others in Brazil, and that is why SCOs, networks and social movements are claiming for the creation of a National Council for FA with the participation of civil society representatives - like we have for health, cities, food security, social assistance, among others. It is also important to say that the different federal bodies which implement direct cooperation with other countries donâ€™t publish their strategy or plan either.  An exception is the humanitarian area of FA: they created a Working Group involving 15 Ministries and SCOs representatives to discuss priorities. It is a Presidential Decree (21/6/2006)

No, it is not published, but it must exist since it is a department of FA, so it must have an internal budget. We had a look a the PPA - PluriAnual Plan 2012-2015 and we could only find general information for FA and nothing especific for ABC. (http://www.planejamento.gov.br/secretarias/upload/Arquivos/spi/publicacoes/Orientacoes_para_Elaboracao_do_PPA_2012-2015.pdf)   It is important to stress that the agency has very few civil servants working for the agency. Most of the staff are hired with resources coming from projects.
I don't know, but I think it doesn't exist since the strategic document is not available, as well as the annual budget.

This is a tricky question for Brazil, since most of its international cooperation (withdrowing contributions to multilateral bodies) is technical cooperation. In this case, the ABC structered a sistem to administrate and monitor the projects, called SIGAP: http://www.abc.gov.br/sigap/

This is a difficult question to answer because theoretically all the 60 or so federal bodies that are involved in international cooperation should publish their tenders by law. To have a clear answer, we should consult this federal organizations or consult the federal site that publishes all the federal tenders: http://www.comprasnet.gov.br/ ABC doesn't publish tenders.
result_comments: As we focusing on Aid given by the Brazilian MFA, of which ABC is department, I have scored a '2' based on this comment: 'ABC doesn't publish tenders.' - JA from Publish

result_evidence: The ABC does not publish it and does not collect it either. But, the official audit bodies, internal and external do the Executive (CGU and TCU) audit the agency as well as the other federal organization that cooperate with other countries.

The Aid Effectiveness Action Plan for 2009-12 is on-line at http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/INET/IMAGES.NSF/vLUImages/About_CIDA/$file/AIDEFFECTIVENESS_ACTIONPLAN_2009-12-e.pdf  Beyond this Action Plan, CIDA has also produced three thematic strategies on the following:  1) Food security - http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/acdi-cida/ACDI-CIDA.nsf/eng/FRA-101515656-QEV 2) Children and youth - http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/acdi-cida/ACDI-CIDA.nsf/eng/FRA-1015151610-QLN and  3) Sustainable economic growth - http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/acdi-cida/ACDI-CIDA.nsf/eng/FRA-101515146-QKD  All official development assistance is also governed by the Official Development Assistance Accountability Act http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/acdi-cida/ACDI-CIDA.nsf/eng/FRA-121185349-JB8

CIDA publishes a range of Annual Reports. These included the following:  Report to Parliament on the ODA Accountability Act (SIx months after the end of the fiscal year) http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/INET/IMAGES.NSF/vLUImages/ODAA/$file/ODAAA-2010-2011-EN.pdf  Departmental Performance Report (approximately one year after the previous fiscal year) http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/dpr-rmr/2010-2011/inst/ida/idatb-eng.asp  Report on Plans and Priorities (Published in April or May and forward looking for coming fiscal year)  http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/rpp/2012-2013/inst/ida/ida-eng.pdf  And the ODA Statistical Report (Published one year after the previous fiscal year and reporting on that previous fiscal year). http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/acdi-cida/ACDI-CIDA.nsf/eng/ANN-321112057-KZN  CIDA also began to produce a Development Results Report, more geared towards public consumption, but has not produced a new one since 2009-2010 http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/acdi-cida/ACDI-CIDA.nsf/eng/NAD-325132025-NCB#pdf

result_comments: CIDA publishes details on various aid allocation policies and procedures related to the Canadian Partnership Branch (for its calls-for-proposals) - See Like above  There are some details on Geographic and Multilateral programs, but not as much information on procedures.  http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/Programs   CIDA also produces forward looking aid allocations in its Report on Plans and Priorities, but at an aggregate level, broken down by Fragile states and crisis- affected communities, Low-income countries, Middle-income countries, Global engagement and strategic policy, and Canadian engagement for development. The Report does identify thematic areas of work looking forward, but does not break down forward-looking allocations either by theme or country. http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/acdi-cida/ACDI-CIDA.nsf/eng/NAD-1019143840-PV8

It is not 100% certain whether such allocations by country, program or institution over the next three years exist. Given the government produces three year forward looking projections, aggregated by type of country (e.g. LIC, MIC), I have to assume such a forward looking budget exists.  It does provide a projection for some institutions and countries for the current fiscal year and following year. On-line at http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/acdi-cida/ACDI-CIDA.nsf/eng/CAR-326103431-K4M
The Handbook was last updated in 2004.

result_review: Canada PeerReviewer: The last paragraph of the Evidence should be removed. The report on ODA Accountability Act is not relevant to this question, and CIDA is not the lead in reporting to Parliament on whole-of-government allocation. CIDA coordinates the publication of the report, but each accountable Minister reports to Parliament on his/her ODA activities.

result_comments: In general, CIDA provides information at an aggregate level on budget support, project-type interventions, scholarships, debt relief and some break down of administrative costs. This is included in their annual statistical report, but is not disaggregated to the activity or country level. It is therefore safe to assume that CIDA collects this type of data, but just does not currently publish it.

By definition, all support from CIDA is in the form of grants. That said, across the three projects used to evaluate project-level transparency, CIDA distinguishes between three types of finance: contribution, grant and contract.  The distinction between the different types of finance would carry much more significance if all government departments allocating international assistance (in particular Finance Canada and Foreign Affairs) signed on to IATI,

result_review: Canada PeerReviewer: The proposed score is N/A, but this option is not offered. The question is about planned expenditures. The IATI standard does not require the publication of planned expenditures.  Expenditures can be reported as transactions, defined as 'the outlay by the implementing agency on goods and services for the activity'. This would not be applicable under CIDA's business model.   - As no information is provided on future expenditures or disburesements, I agree with the score of '2'- JA from Publish

result_comments: CIDA does not publish the conditions, and it is unclear whether they collect them.
result_review: Canada PeerReviewer: Since the reviewer appears  unsure whether such information is collected, the appropriate answer would appear to be 'Don't Know', as per the instructions provided for the survey.  - Appropriate answer would be either be '1' or '2' as CIDA either collects or doesn't collect terms and conditions of the projects. The confidence of the CSO researcher in choosing between 1 and 2 is immaterial to the scoring criteria, and there are no instructions requiring researchers to put 'don't know' when choosing between criteria 1 and 2. As the donor is best placed to make this distinction, the burden to distinguish between 1 and 2 can be considered to be the donor's. In this specific case, as it is nearly inconceivable that no terms and conditions would be collected by any donor, 2 will remain the score- JA from Publish

This question is problematic since the standard for this information has not been developed.   - Appropriate answer is either 1 or 2. result_comments: To assess Freedom of Information Acts for bilateral donors, we are using the Right to Information Rating published by AccessInfo and the Center for Law and Democracy. The RTI Rating uses a 150-point scale, which we have broken down into a four-point scale:   1= No Freedom of Information Act  2= score of 1-60 on the RTI Rating  3= score of 61-90 on the RTI Rating  4= score of 91-150 on the RTI Rating   Donor scored 72 on the 150 point scale
China Aid Policy of 2011

This type of aid is consequently always â€œtiedâ€. For procurement, EXIM Bank publishes its rules that state that at least 50% of goods and services will have to come from China. (see Grimm et al., Transparency of Chinese Aid'; no changes).

Freedom of Information policies for Climate Finance Funds were scored as follows. If the Fund has it's own policy, this was scored in line with our FOIA scoring for DFI and IFI. If the Fund uses the policies of other donors, given that many climate funds work in close collaboration with other IFIs, the climate fund must make specific reference to those policies, so that someone seeking to make a freedom of information request would be guided to the correct institution. Then, we will assign the score of that institution to the climate fund.   Scoring as follows:  (1): No policy, no reference to relevant policies  (2-4)- Policy exists, or clear reference to the relevant policy is made.   Donor does not have its own policy, but the Note on Disclosure of document, cited above, makes repeated reference to the World Bank's disclosure policy. As the World Bank scores a 2 on their disclosure policy, this was given to the donor.
The Climate Investment Funds publish an annual report The Secretariat reports twice yearly to the CTF Trust Fund Committee and this is published.

To assess Freedom of Information Acts for bilateral donors, we are using the Right to Information Rating published by AccessInfo and the Center for Law and Democracy. The RTI Rating uses a 150-point scale, which we have broken down into a four-point scale:   1= No Freedom of Information Act  2= score of 1-60 on the RTI Rating  3= score of 61-90 on the RTI Rating  4= score of 91-150 on the RTI Rating   Donor does not have FOI legislation.

The last time this document was published was in 2009. The original publication stated that it covers the period 2006-2010. More recently the national agency has claimed that the strategy remains the same for the period 2011-2015. Therefore no new document has been published.
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: The strategy is published on our website (http://www.cyprusaid.gov.cy/planning/cyprusaid.nsf/page06_en/page06_en?OpenDocument). The goals of the strategy that covered the period 2006-2010 continues to also apply for the period 2011-2015.

result_comments: The above url gives an indication of some of the aid commitments of Cyprus as these were known in 2009. There is no annual report published and we are uncertain whether a report is produced, even if not published, on an annual basis. We are aware that the national agency collects evidence every year on what has been spent by each ministry which may count as aid.
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: CyprusAid does not publish a narrative annual report. Our annual statistics however, which are approved by the OECD DAC Committee, give an overview on the amount of ODA provided each year, and also provide information on the amount of assistance provided to our parnter countries as well as our contributions to International Organisations. CyprusAid's website include this kind of information. The website also includes information on all projects financed by CyprusAid as well as other relevant information (i.e scholarships etc).

result_comments: The decision for aid allocation is made at a political level. The national agency then looks for possible projects that may be funded through the delegated cooperation method and makes recommendations to the foreign ministry. The selections is made and nothing is published.
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: CyprusAid does have aid allocation policy and procedure. This is descriped in the Medium Term Strategy, available on our website (http://www.cyprusaid.gov.cy/planning/cyprusaid.nsf/page06_en/page06_en?OpenDocument).

result_comments: The evidence is not published and we understand that it does not exist.  It is important to note that aid figures are never known (not even roughly) in advance and that the figures are determined retrospectively when the national agency collects information from the ministries on what each ministry spent which may count as AID (on OSCE criteria) What is known at the start of each year is that part which is allocated as bilateral aid.
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: The budgeting of the necessary funds is being  carried out annually, with a three year budgeting horizon. That is budgets are being prepared and approved annually, but each year each Service makes a three year budgeting projection. CyprusAid's budget (bilateral component) is not published on our website. It can be however located on the website of the Ministry of Finance, under the section 'State budget'  (http://www.mof.gov.cy/mof/mof.nsf/All/5E8F322542536B20C2257929002AD276?OpenDocument).

result_comments: We are not sure if it exists but we have never been given an indication that such a document exists.
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: CyprusAid's annual forward planning budget for assistance to different countries and institutions for the next three years, is not publishded on our website. However, information on what it is expected to be paid in the current year and in the following years (for projects that the implementation period its more than one year), for projects that an Agreement is already signed, is available on our website, in the section of partner countries-development assistance (http://www.cyprusaid.gov.cy/planning/cyprusaid.nsf/index_en/index_en?OpenDocument). In that section, projects currently being implemented, show their disbursment cycle.

result_comments: Cyprus' bilateral aid is distributed primarily through the delegated cooperation method - therefore Cyprus does not define or employ its own procurement policy. But neither does the national agency announce on its web site how procurement proceeds on the projects that it funds through other partners.
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: CyprusAid implements projects using the delegated cooperation method. Therefore, all procurement is done by the Lead Donor according to its rules and regulations on procurement. CyprusAid does not publish any information on this, as it does not get involved on the procurement procedures made by the Lead Donor.

result_comments: The national agency does not publish tenders in relation to projects that it funds through the delegated cooperation method.
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: CyprusAid implements projects using the delegated cooperation method. Therefore, all procurement is done by the Lead Donor according to its rules and regulations on procurement. CyprusAid does not publish any information on this, as it does not get involved on the procurment procedures made by the Lead Donor.

result_comments: It does not publish an annual audit of its aid programmes.
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: CyprusAid implements projects using the delegated cooperation method. Audit clauses however, are included in the Delegated Cooperation Agreements signed between CyprusAid and the Lead Donors, which have the responsibility of auditing the projects implemented on behalf of CyprusAid. Audit reports, are always forwarded to CyprusAid, after the completion of the projects, for information purposes as well as for other actions that we deemed appropriate. The Audit reports are not available on CyprusAid's website.

result_comments: Not only is it not comprehensive, it has only been uploaded for the first time in the past few weeks as we came close to the Presidency. What exists now is the database created for OECD.
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: All information on activities undertaken in partner countries (development assistance) is available on our website (www.cyprusaid.gov.cy).

result_comments: We would feel inclined to tick number 1 above since we know that Cyprus follows primarily political criteria for the selection of countries and once it has selected the recipients looks for other countries that implement projects in those countries so as to enter into a delegated cooperation  approach. Being severely understaffed the agency limits itself to the absolutely necessary activities. In any case, the relevant website does not provide any information on the recipient countries.
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: There is no country strategy paper for each of the recipient countries. CyprusAid strategy however, is guided for all countries by the the 'Medium Term Strategy', which can be located on our website (http://www.cyprusaid.gov.cy/planning/cyprusaid.nsf/page06_en/page06_en?OpenDocument)  - Changed to a 1 based on donor comments- JA

result_comments: Cyprus does not update its data on regular intervals. Therefore its commitments are never clear from the start though they can become clear once the website has been updated - this does not happen regularly but sparingly.
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: For all projects financed by CyprusAid, the disbursment cycle of the project is published on our website. In the cases where the project is about to be implemented in a three year period of time, then forward planning budget for the next three years, will be noted in our website. If a project is financed for more/or less than three years, then the planning budget of the activity, will adjust accordinly. (http://www.cyprusaid.gov.cy/planning/cyprusaid.nsf/page08_en/page08_en?OpenDocument). As regards the score, we noted the score 3, with the clarification that CyprusAid publishes it when the project has disbursment horizon of more than two years.

result_comments: It is not published. Though it is unlikely that Cyprus sings an MOU with the recipient country. Rather it is likely that an MOU is signed with the country to which responsibility is delegated - through the 'delegated responsibility approach of the Republic of Cyprus  - Changed to a 12 based on review- JA
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: CyprusAid does not publish the Memorandum of Understanding that it signs with the Lead Donor in each recipient country. In the cases where the project is implemented by the Government of the recipient country (i.e cases of Lesotho, Mali, Bosnia and Herzegovina etc), with the collaboration of the Lead Donor, the Lead Donor signs an Agrement with the recipient Government. Both auditing and evaluation reports are forwarded to CyprusAid, after the completion of the project. Also, frequent narrative and financial reports are forwarded from the Lead Donor to CyprusAid throughout the implementation of the project, in order to evaluate the progress of the project.

In collecting the information for Aidwatch I have repeatedly been told that aid is not formally treated as tied even though there is some understanding that technical assistance plus refugee financing - supposing that it is treated as legitimate ODA - could be treated as tied. Yes, though as with the case of climate finance - which Cyprus seems to be classifying, for the first time, as ODA - there was a pledge of 1.8 million which I was told would be distributed to the specific project in NEPAL but in reality Cyprus is seeking to postpone the spending due to the financial difficulties of the Republic of Cyprus. It is now presented as if the pledge was for climate finance in general rather than the NEPAL project more specifically.
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: The amount allocated in each project, is stated in the Agreement signed between the Lead Donor and CyprusAid. The amount committed, as well as the disbursment horizon of the project, is published on our website, under the section 'Partner Countries - Development Assistance'. As regards the comment published above, it is noted that the pledge of 1.8 million it was made by Cyprus for fast start initiative, at the European Council meeting of 10-11 December 2009, in the run-up to the Copenhagen Conference. During that Meeting ,Cyprus pledged the amount of â‚¬1.8 mln for climate change, to be distributed during the period 2010-2012 (and not for NEPAL only) (600.000 Euro for 2010, 600.000 Euro for 2011 and 600.000 Euro for 2012). For the first 600.000 Euro (the 2010 tranche), Cyprus has signed a Delegated Cooperation Arrangement with the European Commission, through the â€œGlobal Climate Change Allianceâ€, for financing the project 'Building Climate Resilience in Nepal', which is jointly financed by the European Commission, the United Kingdom and the Republic of Cyprus. Cyprus is currently negotiating with the European Commission for the allocation of the remaining amount of the value of â‚¬1.2, which will be distributed to the Annual Actual Programme of 2013.

result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: Since CyprusAid implements activities using the Delegated Cooperation Method, it does not apply any terms and conditions on the way the project will be implemented (i.e procurement methods etc). The way the project will be implemented and any terms and conditions it may apply on the project, depends on the Lead Donor. CyprusAid can intervene only in the cases where the implementation of the project is not progressing as originally planned and agreed between the two Donors (CyprusAid and Lead Donor).

result_comments: Cyprus tends to rest on the fact that it employs the the delegated responsibility method as an explanation for not publishing any details relating to the implementation of the related projects
result_review: Cyprus PeerReviewer: CyprusAid finances projects that are ready to start, or at a stage very near to that. Therefore, at the negotiation stage between CyprusAid and the Lead Donor regarding the project, CyprusAid evaluates the project and all supporting documents (and in most cases the design documents and logframes) thoroughly. The comment mentioned above that 'Cyprus tends to rest on the fact that it employs the the delegated responsibility method as an explanation for not publishing any details relating to the implementation of the related projects' is not correct, as it gives the impression that CyprusAid does not evaluate the project before the signing of any Agreement.

Cyprus PeerReviewer: Some projects are implemented using the help and the syupport of the Government of the recipient country. For example, in Lesotho all projects implemented so far, were implemented by IrishAid with the help of the Ministry of Education of Lesotho, as IrishAid has close collaboration with the Government of Lesotho. Another example are the projects implemented in Mali, where BTC has so far implemented the projects using the help and the support of the Government of Mali. Also, in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the project is implemented by the Veterinary Office of Bosnia and Herzegovina with the supervision of the Swedish Development Agency, which CyprusAid has signed a Delegated Cooperation Agreement. This kind of collaboration between the Lead Donor and the recipient country,  link the activity to the recipient government's relevant budget classifications (as it burdens the Government with administration costs). Furthermore, in these cases the projects, after their implementation, are maintained by the recipient Government's budget (as it will become property of the that Government).

result_comments: To assess Freedom of Information Acts for bilateral donors, we are using the Right to Information Rating published by AccessInfo and the Center for Law and Democracy. The RTI Rating uses a 150-point scale, which we have broken down into a four-point scale:   1= No Freedom of Information Act  2= score of 1-60 on the RTI Rating  3= score of 61-90 on the RTI Rating  4= score of 91-150 on the RTI Rating   Donor scored 69 on the 150 point scale
Assessed on 07/08/2012

result_comments: The Bank publishes its sectorial policies (transport, energy) and its overall mission  To score a '4' we would need a strategy paper that describes the priorities and strategies of EBRD as a whole, rather than seperate strategies for countries and sectors. The mission page is insufficiently detailed in this regard.- JA from Publish What You Fund.
result_review: EBRD PeerReviewer: The strategic objectives and sectoral priorities are outlined in the Capital Resource Review (CRR) document (subject to review every five years). The Bank disclosed the summary of the CRR4 on the website at http://www.ebrd.com/pages/about/policies/capres.shtml. As part of the fourth Capital Resources Review (CRR4), the EBRD sought an open exchange of views with all its stakeholders and made relevant working papers available to the public, civil society organisations and other actors. Several hundred CSOs from the countries of operations and shareholder countries were invited to provide written feedback on the CRR4 material.  In addition, the EBRD organised a consultation workshop on 10 March 2010 at the Bank's HQ in London to provide the opportunity for regional and international civil society stakeholders - including NGOs, think tanks, academics and other parties - to discuss strategic aspects of CRR4.  The Basic Documents of the EBRD contain, among other documents, the Agreement Establishing the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which describes the mandate and mission of the Bank  http://www.ebrd.com/pages/research/publications/institutional/basicdocs.shtml

EBRD PeerReviewer: The EBRD investment projects: http://www.ebrd.com/pages/workingwithus/projects.shtml The EBRD donor â€“ financed technical cooperation (TCs) assignments: http://www.ebrd.com/pages/research/publications/flagships/donor.shtml

result_comments: Fourth Capital Resources Review strategy and framework (CRR4) on which the annual budget 2012 is based,  covers the period 2011 to 2015 however it does not contain detailed figures.
result_review: EBRD PeerReviewer: The summary of the Annual budget and business plan objectives are published at http://www.ebrd.com/pages/about/policies/businessplan.shtml   - The Annual Budget published does not cover beyond 2012. PWYF Guideline state that we will accept indicative or projected figures. This document   http://www.ebrd.com/downloads/policies/capital/crr1115.pdf  states:   'The Bankâ€™s annual business volume (ABV) should increase to up to â‚¬9 billion in 2010 and in the first two years of the CRR4 period before declining to a maximum of â‚¬8.5 billion during 2013-15. The Board of Directors would continue to set annual business plan targets within these limits. This ABV path would allow the Bank to frontload its activity in the most difficult years. Implementing this strategy will require additional resources. Specifically, the Bank would over the CRR4 period need: ï‚· an increase in staffing in the range of 100 to 170 (7-12 percent); and ï‚· a cumulative real increase in the budget of between 13 and 19 percent. The additional staff needs are driven by the further deepening of the Bankâ€™s engagement in the early transition countries and in climate change, the added emphasis on policy dialogue, an almost one-third increase in the annual number of new projects and the need to monitor a growing portfolio. Based on full utilisation of the ABV envelope, and prudent operational assumptions, the Bankâ€™s portfolio of projects would grow by 38 percent during the CRR4 period to â‚¬44 billion at the end of 2015, while operating assets would grow by 45 percent to â‚¬32 billion. Financial projections indicate that the Bankâ€™s capital structure would continue to meet the prudential criteria established in the Bankâ€™s recently adopted Economic Capital Policy, but statutory capital utilisation thresholds would be significantly exceeded on the basis of the current capital.'  We see this a sufficient to score a 4- JA

Enlargement Strategy and Report 2011 sets out both the Strategy on the part of the EC for the coming year as well as report on the situation for the previous (2011) year. I am not aware of any specific (administrative) report on the work of DG Enlargement.  When assessing the budgets and report I took into consideration just the data published for direct aid, not the costs of operation/administration on the part of the DG Enlargement, EU Delegations etc. I have never see this shared myself.

DG Enlargement publishes multi-annual indicative financial framework including allocations per country and sectors.The last one (see 1st link) published is for period 2012-2013. There is not specific documents on aid allocation policy and procedures for DG Enlargement as part of the European Commission the DG follows the rules set out bin the PRAG-Practical Guide to contract procedures for EU external action (see 2nd link).

DG Enlargement publishes multi, usually 3-yearly indicative financial frameworks within the 7year planning cycle. The current planning/budgeting cycle is 2007-2013 and the last multi-annual planning framework is a 2-year one 2012-2013 (see link). The Commission is currently negotiating (there is a draft out) it next 7-year budget for 2014-2020, including the DG Enlargement budget, so the budget details for period from 2014 are not available.  Upgraded to 4 - EC proposal for the MFF contains sufficient information on indicative amounts for this indicator. - MB from Publish What You Fund
The link is to the MIPF 2012-2013 (see previous question for explanation why it is a 2, not 3-year framework).
Again, as explained before this is in PRAG.

Under EU rules, open/restricted procurement relates to how many bidders/competitors/subject the tender/CfP is open and not country. I.e. aid is always programmes for a particular region and country and usually can not be shifted from one to another country. Also, the state budget is always made for 1 year at a time and budgeting for development cooperation for a longer period would have to set a precedent. â€¢	Estonia has a national strategy plan for development cooperation and humanitarian aid, which proposes the expected allocations for aid until 2015 (http://www.vm.ee/sites/default/files/arengukoostoo-humanitaarabi_arengukava_2011-2015.pdf, p. 28), but the concrete allocations will be decided each year--- JA from Publish

Announcement of calls for proposals: (1) The ministry shall announce an open call for proposals by publishing an invitation to submit proposals in at least one national daily newspaper and on its website. There shall be a period of at least 50 working days between the announcement of an open call for proposals and the due date of submission of proposals. (2) The ministry shall announce a restricted call for proposals by sending invitations to submit proposals to applicants chosen by the ministry. The invitations to submit proposals shall provide for a sufficient period for preparation of proposals.  Source: http://www.vm.ee/sites/default/files/Abi_andmise_kord.pdf

Other conditions are outlined in the calls for proposals, which are announced as follows: (1) The ministry shall announce an open call for proposals by publishing an invitation to submit proposals in at least one national daily newspaper and on its website. There shall be a period of at least 50 working days between the announcement of an open call for proposals and the due date of submission of proposals. (2) The ministry shall announce a restricted call for proposals by sending invitations to submit proposals to applicants chosen by the ministry. The invitations to submit proposals shall provide for a sufficient period for preparation of proposals. (3) An invitation to submit proposals shall set out at least the following information: 1) the due date of submission of proposals; 2) the address for submission of proposals; 3) the budget of funds envisaged for the call for proposals; and 4) references to additional information.
Only the total sum is published.

The EIBâ€™s financing allocations , policies and instruments are published on the website. For regions outside the EU in which the EIB operates based on a mandate given by the EU, the particularities under each mandate are also explained.Strategic Plan 2012-2014 has sections detailing allocation priorities both within and outside the EU.

Rolling 3-year Operational Plan is published every year, and indicates the envisaged financing volumes and the high-level operational priorities applicable to financing activities in the Neighbourhood and Partner countries.However, a full score would require that a budget be provided up to 2015, current operational plan only to 2014.
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: For activities outside the EU, the EIB is operating based on mandates given by the EU that determine financing ceilings on a multiannual basis. The COP is the document that comes closest to what can be considered a development budget or forward planning budget for a classical aid agency. The EIBâ€™s Cooperate Operational Plan (COP) is always published on a rolling basis at the beginning of the year and covers a three year period. E.g., in 2012 the COP was published in February and covers the years 2012, 2013, 2014 (i.e. three years).   http://www.eib.org/infocentre/publications/all/operational-plan-2012-2014.htm

result_comments: The Bank publishes only headline figures, financial ceilings but this cannot be treated as budget.   For activities outside the EU, the EIB is operating based on mandates given by the EU or its Member States that determine financing ceilings on a multiannual basis. The Corporate Operational Plan is the document that comes closest to what can be considered a development budget or forward planning budget for a classical aid agency. the current COP contains only information on planned  total disbursements and signatures for outside of the EU.
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: The EIB does not operate based on forward planning budgets for individual countries or institutions.  Such forward looking budgets or plans are not produced in EIB.    The business model on which basis the EIB operates as a financing institution does in fact not allow such a detailed forward planning.  For example, the EIB signs finance contracts with a counterpart for the financing of a particular activity. However, one cannot say at what moment these funds will actually be disbursed. It is up to the counterpart to request the disbursement. The disbursement is therefore much more demand driven as in a grant making institution.   -- It is possible that we would be prepared to accept their headline figures from p5 of http://www.eib.org/attachments/strategies/cop_2012_en.pdf   which states amounts projected for inside and outside the EU, ACP investment facility, JESSICA. However, it still doesn't go beyond end Dec 2014 so cannot score higher than 3 anyway.  - JA from Publish

result_comments: P17 of the Guide to Procurement says the Bank requires the promoter to publish a Procurement Notice in the Official Journal of the European Union.  If necessary, the  Bank will assist in arranging such publication on behalf of the promoter.  OJEU Tenders publicly available at Tenders Direct website.
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: The EIB has to follow EU procurement rules and procedures. All tenders that are put to invite bids for the operation of the institution (for its own account) are published. Calls for tender for EIB projects are listed in the Official Journal of the European Union. This is mandatory for all non-EU projects.   For EIB financed activities carried out by private sector counterparts, EIB encourages such counterparts to publish a tender notice in the Official Journal of the European Union and adopt open or restricted procedures, particularly for large contracts.  Tenders for EIB technical assistance are always published on the technical assistance section of the website.  http://www.eib.org/about/procurement/index.htm  http://ted.europa.eu/udl?uri=TED:NOTICE:207671-2012:TEXT:EN:HTML&src=0  http://www.eib.org/attachments/med/ta_femip_projects_en.pdf

result_comments: Financing transactions and the implementation progress of the projects financed are monitored annually but the EIB does not publish the monitoring reports.
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: The audit of the EIBâ€™s annual accounts, financial statements of all its activities (inside and outside EU) is always published.  http://www.eib.org/infocentre/publications/all/audit-committee-annual-reports-2011.htm   http://www.eib.org/attachments/general/reports/fr2011en.pdf  http://www.eib.org/attachments/country/if_financial_statements_2011_en.pdf

result_comments: The EIB does not base its activities on country strategy papers drawn-up in-house for the different countries it is active in. Outside the Union, EIB lending is governed by a series of mandates from the European Union in support of EU development and cooperation policies in partner countries. The Bank claims is bases its financing objectives on the country or sector priorities laid down in the relevant strategic documents drawn-up by the European Commission and that the country strategy paper that are in this respect relevant for the EIB and are all published by the European External Action Servive: http://www.eeas.europa.eu/sp/index_en.htm Nevertheless the Bank does not refer to those country strategy papers in its own documents, does not provide links to those papers as well as does not justify lending operations with the strategy drawn up in the papers.
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: The EIB does not base its activities on country strategy papers drawn-up in-house for the different countries it is active in. Such documents do not exist. This is due to its character as a policy implementing institution (policy is made by other EU institutions).   EIB activities are governed by objectives laid down in the different mandates the Bank receives from the EU institutions. But these mandates do not provide a country break-down. For example, for activities in the ACP (Africa, Caribbean and the Pacific) region, the objectives are defined by the Cotonou Agreement (http://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/where/acp/overview/documents/cotonou-consolidated-fin-ap-2012_en.pdf)  EIB is basing its financing objectives also on the country or regional priorities stipulated in the relevant strategic documents drawn-up by the European Commission and the European External Action Service (EEAS). These documents could be considered as EIB equivalents for â€œownâ€ country strategy papers.  Jointly with the EEAS, EIB will draw-up regional technical operational guidelines (until the end of 2012) that will be published once finalised.  http://www.eeas.europa.eu/sp/index_en.htm  http://www.eeas.europa.eu/sp/region_en.htm  http://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/where/acp/overview/documents/cotonou-consolidated-fin-ap-2012_en.pdf

EIB PeerReviewer: The EIB does not operate based on forward planning budgets for individual countries or institutions.  Such forward looking budgets or plans are not produced in EIB.    The business model on which basis the EIB operates as a financing institution does in fact not allow such a detailed forward planning.  For example, the EIB signs finance contracts with a counterpart for the financing of a particular activity. However, one cannot say at what moment these funds will actually be disbursed. It is up to the counterpart to request the disbursement. The disbursement is therefore much more demand driven as in a grant making institution.    -- Accept that there are no indicative figures for countries for next three years but think there probably are for regions given mid-term review of their mandate (see p 53) Even if so, would only be a 3.   http://www.eib.org/attachments/documents/eib_external_mandate_2007-2013_mid-term_review.pdf  See for instance, on Central Asia  http://www.eib.org/projects/regions/central-asia/index.htm -- JA from Publish

result_comments: EIB signs Framework Agreements with the countries however the bank does not publish them. The Bank signs also Financial Contract with the project promoter however it is also not published

The Bank does not conduct evaluation for individual projects but it does evaluation for sector lending operations in the region. Nevertheless in 2011 the Bank did not conduct any evaluation which would refer to its lending outside of the EU.
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: Evaluations are carried out for a selection of projects and published under the evaluations section on the EIB website.   http://www.eib.org/projects/evaluation/index.htm

result_comments: The Bank does not publish results, outcomes and outputs for completed activities. Often it does not even update its project information document.
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: Evaluations are carried out for a selection of projects and published under the evaluations section on the EIB website.  http://www.eib.org/projects/evaluation/index.htm

result_comments: The database of all projects is available online however it does not show the stage of the project. For example, for the assessment of project compliance with the environmental and social standards the project's stage is important. Nevertheless the bank does not publish finance information whether the financial resources have been disbursed or not. In the category 'project financed' the Bank publish projects which were not in fact financed.   Also the information is often out dated, for example for a project signed in 2007 'Sisecam Glass' the project information states 'an EIA has already been performed for the coating line and is underway for the float line, which will be verified during appraisal.' The appraisal has already been completed and project most probably financed but the EIB information has not not updated.
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: EIB has an online database showing all its activities in an individual country, providing comprehensive information (name of project, location, objectives, sector, description, environmental & social information, procurement, financing volume, project cost, status, etc.).  As a general remark, the publication of project information is governed by the EIB's Transparency Policy: http://www.eib.org/about/publications/eib-transparency-policy.htm. The policy is based on an assumption for disclosure but provides for exceptions in cases where publication of information would undermine e.g. commercial interests of the promoter. The EIB is bound to comply with those provisions (!) and must not publish information such as disbursement levels as this information would undermine the commercial interests of the private sector counterpart.   http://www.eib.org/projects/pipeline/regions/index.htm

result_comments: The EIB works closely with the European Commission, combining grants and loans in the pre-Accession region to achieve an optimum financing package'. However the Bank does not publish information whether a financing operation is supported by a grant along with EIB's own risk lending.
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: EIB always finances only a part of an activity. The remaining part for the activity has to come from the promoter's own resources or other parties' financing. This is clearly stated on the website (http://www.eib.org/projects/faq/loan_applications/index.htm).   Sometimes it is stated whether the activity is e.g. a Public-Private â€“Partnership or carried out jointly with other bi- or multilaterals.   http://www.eib.org/projects/pipeline/2009/20090678.htm  http://www.eib.org/projects/press/2012/2012-073-albania-eur-35-m-for-fier-by-pass.htm & http://www.eib.org/projects/pipeline/2007/20070204.htm & http://www.eib.org/projects/pipeline/2009/20090172.htm
EIB PeerReviewer: This is not categorised, neither is it collected. However, Type of financial instrument (loan, credit line) is always published.

result_comments: The Bank provides also technical assistance but it is not published on project level
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: As a Bank, EIB provides finance not â€œgrant aidâ€. However, limited technical assistance (coming from different individual financing facilities) is provided on a project-level basis. This is not indicated in the project database but published on the technical assistance section of the website. It is also published in the annual reports of individual financing facilities (e.g. the Investment Facility).   http://www.eib.org/attachments/med/ta_femip_projects_en.pdf  http://www.eib.org/attachments/country/if_annual_report_2010_en.pdf

result_comments: The Bank claims that unique activity identifier is publish and constitute a part of the URL. However this is not obvious to the webpage viewers, probably it is known only to EIB itself.
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: Each project has a unique activity identifier which is contained in the URL of the project at the website. See the last 8 digits of the URL. This is the complete project code as it is used internally.   http://www.eib.org/projects/pipeline/2010/20100205.htm
EIB PeerReviewer: Not applicable. EIB does not provide aid. Procurement is untied but has to be in line with EU procurement rules.

result_comments: EIB publish information whether the project was signed or not. Signing of the financial contract does not mean that the project was financed. Information on further stages is not published by the bank.
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: The project database indicates information about the status of a project, i.e. â€œunder appraisalâ€, â€œsignedâ€, â€œapprovedâ€   http://www.eib.org/projects/pipeline/index.htm?start=2008&end=2012&status=Â®ion=&country=Â§or=

result_comments: Contact details for the EIB are not published. In case of Credit Line loan there is contact to the borrower provided.
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: For each project activity, contact details for the EIB's central information desk are provided (â€œcontact usâ€).  For some projects even the contact information of the implementing entity is provided.  http://www.eib.org/projects/pipeline/2012/20120149.htm   http://www.eib.org/projects/pipeline/2008/20080263.htm

result_comments: The Bank does not publish its appraisal reports even those containing environmental information. This stands openly against EIB's obligations under the Aarhus Convention.
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: In case where an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) is required, the EIA is published.  http://www.eib.org/projects/documents/20060238_nts.htm

result_comments: Terms and conditions are contained in the financial contract which is not published, neither in parts.
Only the total estimated cost is published
The financial contract is not published
Only Non-Technical Summary of the Environmental Impact Assessment is published
This is not published and I do not know if this is collected
result_review: EIB PeerReviewer: Neither published nor collected.

result_comments: To assess Freedom of Information Acts for bilateral donors, we are using the Right to Information Rating published by AccessInfo and the Center for Law and Democracy. The RTI Rating uses a 150-point scale, which we have broken down into a four-point scale:   1= No Freedom of Information Act  2= score of 1-60 on the RTI Rating  3= score of 61-90 on the RTI Rating  4= score of 91-150 on the RTI Rating   Donor scored 105 on the 150 point scale

The FPI publishes strategy papers for one out of two components of the Instrument for Stability: the crisis preparedness/long-term component. It cannot publish anything about the crisis reponse/short term component because it is a flexible component.  FPI also does not publish strategy documents about the other funds it manages (for example the electoral observation missions)
result_review: EC-EEAS PeerReviewer: This clearly is not possible for the crisis-response element, but for all other areas the current strategy doument is always published  - Changed to a 4 based on donor comments- JA

result_comments: FPI does publish an annual report for the Instrument for Stability, but not for its other activities.
result_review: EC-EEAS PeerReviewer: The latest version of the Annual Report has always been published (first report being the 2007 Annual Report)  - Changed to a 4 based on review, 2011 report was published on July 24- JA

result_comments: The allocation policy for the Instrument for Stability is explained in the regulation and the programming documents.   But the procedures for civil society organisations trying to get funding from the crisis response/short term component of the Instrument for Stability is not published. (this is different from getting funding under the crisis prepararedness component / peacebuilding partnership, for which calls for proposals are made public will all other European Commission's calls for proposals)
result_review: EC-EEAS PeerReviewer: Aid allocation policy and procedure is always published for the longer-term component of the Instument for Stability:  Strategy Papers: http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_2012_13_strategy_en.pdf http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_2012_13_strategy_comm_decision_en.pdf http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_2012_13_strategy__annex_en.pdf  Annual Action Programme: http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_pbp_annual_action_programme_2012_comm_dec_en.pdf http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_pbp_aap_annex_summary_2012_en.pdf http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_pbp_aap_annex_2012_en.pdf   - Must remain a 3, as it is reasonable to expect there is some allocation policy to the crisis response aspect of FPI- JA

result_comments: The budget of the Instrument for Stability for 2007-2013 is available. Its planned breakdown into short-term/crisis response component (72%) and long-term/crisis preparedness component (23%) for the same period is published.
result_review: EC-EEAS PeerReviewer: http://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/how/finance/ifs_en.htm  http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=MEMO/11/878&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=en  - As this is only to 2013, remains a 3- JA

EC-EEAS PeerReviewer: The multi-annual forward planning budget is always published for the longer-term programmable component.  http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_strategy_2007-2011_en.pdf http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_2012_13_strategy_en.pdf http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_2012_13_strategy_comm_decision_en.pdf http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_2012_13_strategy__annex_en.pdf  http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_indicative_programme_en.pdf http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/mip_2009_2011_en.pdf   - Would agree that only the long component is needed to score here, but all docs cited by donor only go to 2013, and none of them contain a disaggregated budget. JA

result_comments: FPI publishes most calls for tenders and proposals. But in 2011 FPI launched at least one call for proposals that was not published on the EuropeAid website.
result_review: EC-EEAS PeerReviewer: FPI publishes all tenders save for those that are classified sensitive and cannot be published (very exceptionally)
EC-EEAS PeerReviewer: http://eca.europa.eu/portal/pls/portal/docs/1/9766724.PDF  - Changed to a 4 based on donor comments- JA

result_comments: This database is for all European Commission grants and contracts, but it is not possible to separate what was funded by FPI from the other European Commission instruments.  Only to 2010- JA from Publish What You Fund.

To our knowledge, FPI does not have a specific country strategy paper for its (even bigger) recipient countries. Indeed, the biggest part of the Instrument for Stability is a crisis response mechanism (as explained in the organisation survey) so there cannot be a long- or mid-term planned approach.  However, the European Commission (FPI is a service of the Commission) publishes country strategy papers for the duration of its external financial instruments, i.e. 6 years. The URL for the Pakistan country strategy paper 2007-2013 is indicated above.    - The IfS strategy for 2012-2013 indicates certain planned activities in the country, such as counterterrorism activities in Pakistan (p. 40 of 2009-2011 Multiannual Indicative program). While acknowledging that the short term nature of many IfS's activities precludes it from strategic planning, FPI could score if it (or the Commission) published a document detailing the rationale and aims of planned activities in Pakistan. -- JA from Publish What You Fund
result_review: EC-EEAS PeerReviewer: By it's very nature, assistance via the short-term crisis-response component cannot be programmed.  AThe longer-term programmable assistance, provided in the context of stable conditions for cooperation, is programmed in a Strategy Paper that is always published: http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/index_en.htm#2012   - Agree with donor, but Strategy Paper not broken down by country. Remains a 2- JA

result_comments: To our knowledge, FPI does not publish or have such documents for Pakistan.  Regarding the Instrument for Stability, it is normal that this type of documents does not exist since it is mainly a crisis response mechanism and FPI can hardly anticipate three years in advance the coming crisis.
result_review: EC-EEAS PeerReviewer: Strategy Papers: http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_2012_13_strategy_en.pdf http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_2012_13_strategy_comm_decision_en.pdf http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_2012_13_strategy__annex_en.pdf  Annual Action Programme: http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_pbp_annual_action_programme_2012_comm_dec_en.pdf http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_pbp_aap_annex_summary_2012_en.pdf http://eeas.europa.eu/ifs/docs/ifs_pbp_aap_annex_2012_en.pdf  - No document related to long term program is specific to any country, remains a 1- JA

result_comments: There is no information about it on the Instrument for Stability website.

Such evaluations might be collected but they are not published (or very well hidden in the European Commission websites). There is no link towards suc evaluation on the pages related to the Instrument for Stability.  - In this case, the MOU between the EC and Pakistan on development cooperation (still in force as far as I can tell) is admissable. - JA from Publish.

But 1) it may not cover all current activities; 2) it is not possible to differentiate which of these activities are managed by FPI.  The EU delegation in Pakistan also publishes a list of projects implemented in this country (http://eeas.europa.eu/delegations/pakistan/projects/list_of_projects/projects_en.htm) but it is not possible for us to tell whether this list is comprehensive and updated or not.   Some project lelve data published on IATI registry, but not comprehensive- http://tools.aidinfolabs.org/showmydata/index.php?url=http://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/files/iati/EU_PK.xml -- JA from Publish

result_review: Gates PeerReviewer: Strategy documents are published for most of our programs to provide clarity into our general approach and policies for funding. For example: - Agriculture Development = http://www.gatesfoundation.org/agriculturaldevelopment/Documents/agricultural-development-strategy-overview.pdf - Financial Services for the Poor = http://www.gatesfoundation.org/financialservicesforthepoor/Documents/fsp-strategy-overview.pdf - Water, Sanitation & Hygiene = http://www.gatesfoundation.org/watersanitationhygiene/Documents/wsh-strategy-overview.pdf - Global Health = http://www.gatesfoundation.org/global-health/Documents/global-health-strategy-overview.pdf.

result_comments: Latest is 2010

Strategy Lifecycle paper outlines the process of how Gates Foundation arrives at its funding priorities. 'Our Approach to Grants' outlines their grant-making procedures. However, there is no information on how the three current Gates programs specifically fulfilled the criteria in the Strategy Lifecycle paper. This is needed in order to understand why Gates has pursued projects in these areas to the exclusion of other potential areas.    - PWYF guidelines state that we will 'accept general thematic/regional principles for allocation policy'. There is plenty of information on their website about this, especially:   http://www.gatesfoundation.org/grantseeker/Pages/foundation-grant-making-priorities.aspx   Upgraded to a 4- JA
2011 audit now published.
Note: I have treated the Gates survey like a Development Bank, so rather than a country I have selected their largest international program, the Global Health Program.

No progress reports for Global Health Program, only one Monitoring and Evaluation report, dated 2008, for this program as well. However, there are fairly systematic evaluation reports for grants in the 'Agricultural Development' section, but this is a bit of an exception to the rule: http://www.gatesfoundation.org/learning/Pages/agricultural-development-progress-reports.aspx.
result_review: Gates PeerReviewer: Evaluation reports are published at http://www.gatesfoundation.org/Pages/Search.aspx. Our Ag Development and Financial Services for the Poor programs have reports posted.

Date specified (presumably the start date) and a general 'term' that specifies how long the program is intended to take.  However, it would be useful to explicitly state the planned start and end dates of the project.

The second source states: 'The majority of procurement on behalf of the Alliance is conducted by UNICEF, while GAVI-eligible countries in the Americas are sourcing their vaccines through the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) Revolving Fund.'  UNICEF Supply publishes calls for proposals on its website, but these do not appear to include any historical tenders. PAHO does not appear to publish any tenders.

Freedom of Information policies for Climate Finance Funds were scored as follows. If the Fund has it's own policy, this was scored in line with our FOIA scoring for DFI and IFI. If the Fund uses the policies of other donors, given that many climate funds work in close collaboration with other IFIs, the climate fund must make specific reference to those policies, so that someone seeking to make a freedom of information request would be guided to the correct institution. Then, we will assign the score of that institution to the climate fund.   Scoring as follows:  (1): No policy, no reference to relevant policies  (2-4)- Policy exists, or clear reference to the relevant policy is made.   The donor does not have its own policy, and no information refferring to relevant policies at other institutions could be found.

Resources for the GEF Trust Fund are replenished every four years through a process called the 'GEF Replenishment.' Proposed indicative resourcing envelopes are published within the replenishment programming document. Actually budgets are agreed on an annual basis.

The GEF works though implementing agencies (ADB, AfDB, EBRD, FAO, IDB, IFAD, UNDP, UNEP, UNIDO, WB).  It requires implementing agencies to meet its minimum fiduciary standards which include on procurement - 'Procurement records are easily accessible to procurement staff, and procurement policies and awards are publicly disclosed.'

The GEF works though implementing agencies (ADB, AfDB, EBRD, FAO, IDB, IFAD, UNDP, UNEP, UNIDO, WB).  It requires implementing agencies to meet its minimum fiduciary standards which include requirements on procurement in line with recognised international good practice, but no specific requirement to publish tenders.    - All tenders related to the GEF appear to be traceable through the implementing agencies- 4 - JA

To assess Freedom of Information Acts for bilateral donors, we are using the Right to Information Rating published by AccessInfo and the Center for Law and Democracy. result_review: IADB PeerReviewer: To allow time for learning to better inform the design of the next Country Strategy, there is a transition period of one year that starts at the expiration of the effective Country Strategy. See footnote 26 on the last page of http://idbdocs.iadb.org/wsdocs/getdocument.aspx?docnum=36860357  In the case of Argentina, the most recent Country Strategy was effective until  December 2011 and the transition period extends its coverage up to end of 2012, so that the document currently available is still in effect according to IDB procedure. The new Country Strategy for Argentina is in preparation and scheduled for approval by the end of 2012.

IADB PeerReviewer: All country strategies include a lending/financing section (chapter IV), which presents disbursements planned for the years covered by the country strategy (3 to 5 years). See http://www.iadb.org/en/about-us/country-strategies,7809.html for a list of all country strategies.  In addition, the advanced project search allows to isolate projects in the pipeline (not yet approved), which can be indicative of the resources that will flow to the country in the next five years: http://www.iadb.org/en/projects/advanced-search,1301.html?query=&ProjectNumber=&Status=PIP&Country=AR&Topic=&Sector=&SubSector=&Fund=&Cofinancing=&FinancialProd=&ProjectType=&YearFrom=&YearTo=&FinancingOver=&FinancingUnder=&FinCurrency=&adv=true.

result_review: IADB PeerReviewer: A Country Strategy is developed jointly between each recipient country and the IADB for the provision of aid in that country. As outlined in the â€œIDB Financial Programming Processâ€  (http://www.iadb.org/en/about-us/idb-financial-programming-process-,6237.html), one of the objectives of the Country Strategy is to agree with each borrowing member country the operational program to be carried out with that country, and ensure that the program will contribute effectively and efficiently toward the country's development goals.  A list of country strategies can be found at http://www.iadb.org/en/about-us/country-strategies,7809.html
