result_review: IADB PeerReviewer: The Project Completion Report (PCR) assesses the implementation of the project (outputs) as well as the extent to which it has achieved its outcomes upon project completion. The complete list of PCRs can be accessed through IADB's project document search (http://www.iadb.org/en/projects/search-project-documents,1302.html?keyword=&IDBOperation=&Country=AR&docType=PCR&subregion=&Topic=&fromMonth=&fromYear=&toMonth=&toYear=&projDocLang=&recsPage=10).  In addition, upon the completion of a strategy cycle, the results of that strategy are assessed in a Country Program Evaluation (CPE), which is available at  http://idbdocs.iadb.org/wsdocs/getdocument.aspx?docnum=35157959 . The latest CPE for Argentina is currently in preparation.

result_review: IADB PeerReviewer: The classification of a project as ODA (concessional) or OOF (non-concessional) is based on OECD-DAC terminology. All IDB operations are classified as ODA or OOF in the OECD-DAC Creditor Reporting System (http://stats.oecd.org/qwids/).  In IDB terminology, the â€œflow typeâ€ is based on the fund type (found in the financing section of the project page) and the project type (found in the basic information section of the project page).   All Non-Reimbursable Technical Cooperation operations are classified as ODA. For lending operations, the IDB's Fund for Special Operations (FSO) [http://www.iadb.org/en/about-us/idb-financing/fund-for-special-operations-fso,6063.html] and IDB Grant Facility (GRF) [http://www.iadb.org/en/about-us/idb-financing/idb-grant-facility,3342.html], provide concessional financing to its most vulnerable member countries. Loan operations funded with Ordinary Capital (OC) [http://www.iadb.org/en/about-us/idb-financing/ordinary-capital-resource-callable-capital-and-paid-in-capital-from-the-idb-member-countries,6092.html], are classified as OOF.

result_review: IADB PeerReviewer: Sub-national geographic information is provided in the loan document where relevant. However, in an effort to increase transparency and accountability, the IADB launched MapAmericas (http://www.iadb.org/mapamericas/) during its Annual Meeting last March. MapAmericas provides geo-coded data for project outputs and outcomes (where applicable). It currently covers projects in Bolivia, Guyana, Haiti, Honduras, Nicaragua and Uruguay, with plans to increase the coverage to all IADB borrowing member countries.

IADB PeerReviewer: According to the IADB's Access to Information Policy, public requests for Information may be submitted via the Bank's on-line request form (http://www5.iadb.org/pic/informationrequest.aspx?lang=en). Requests may also be submitted by fax, mail, or email to the Public Information Contact in the relevant Country Office (see www.iadb.org/en/about-us/field-office-public-Information-contacts,7419.html). In addition, there is a â€œcontact usâ€ link at the bottom of every page on the IADB's website (http://www.iadb.org/en/contact-us,1390.html).  For information on a specific activity, the name of the team members can be found on the approved project document and their contact information is available through the IDB Staff Directory http://www.iadb.org/en/about-us/idb-staff-directory,1330.html.

IADB PeerReviewer: The Development Effectiveness Matrix (DEM) was introduced in 2008 to improve the evaluabitily of IADB operations. In 2011, 100% of projects included an economic analysis (see page 35 of the Development Effectiveness Overview, DEO (http://www.iadb.org/document.cfm?id=36726884). These analyses are included in the project document presented for approval and publicly available (http://www.iadb.org/projectDocument.cfm?id=1296855).

For Policy-Based Loans, additional criteria are spelled out in the policy matrix, which is part of the project proposal. result_comments: Ireland's aid is 100% untied.  http://www.irishaid.gov.ie/about.html   'Irish Aid's programme has always been completely untied, that is to say, it is not conditional in any way on the use of Irish goods or services. It is Government policy that Irish Aid's funding should remain untied, as it takes the view that tied aid is less effective in its impact, leads to a proliferation of different standards and technologies in developing countries and can be abused to provide hidden export subsidies. '

Assessed on 07/08/2012

result_review: Romania PeerReviewer: The English version of the Strategy was just temporarily unavailable and is presently fully functional on the www.aod.ro site.

The EN version of the reports for 2007-2010 are here:  http://www.mae.ro/en/node/2062
Romania PeerReviewer: A first document in this sense was just published this week and we intend to continue publishing them the following years.

Romania PeerReviewer: While some perspectives regarding the budget for the next years do exist, we are, in fact, not sure about the funds at our disposal before the beginning of each year, when the national budget is approved by the Parliament. In Romania there are not, in fact, multiannual budgets.  While we consider it would be fair to change the answer, we would, however, suggest that the way in which this questionnaire if formulated seems to reward lack of transparency (i.e. the existence of the budget but not its publishing).

The RTI Rating uses a 150-point scale, which we have broken down into a four-point scale:   1= No Freedom of Information Act  2= score of 1-60 on the RTI Rating  3= score of 61-90 on the RTI Rating  4= score of 91-150 on the RTI Rating   Donor scored 97 on the 150 point scale

CDC's aid allocation policy is available as part of a PowerPoint presentation on its overarching strategy. Similar documents accepted for other donors are typically longer and more detailed papers. The information is very high-level and does not discuss in very much detail the reasons for selecting certain regions, themes, or funds over others. However, we understand that this presentation is the strategy itself and not just a summary, and are accepting it as published on that basis.

While CDC's strategy document pages does show a 2016 projection of portfolio value (p24-25), this is not sufficient detail to count as a total budget: there is no year-by-year breakdown up to 2015.  The annual report does not show a year-by-year projection of future spending for the next three years, even at an indicative level.
result_review: UK-CDC PeerReviewer: On pages 8-9 of the Annual Report and Accounts CDC sets out in detail all the current outstanding fund commitments (i.e. monies that CDC is committed to spending).    http://www.cdcgroup.com/uploads/cdcara20120529.pdf  In CDC's strategy document pages 11-25 set out the strategy for each of the investment divisions, including 2016 projection of portfolio value (p24-25). The document is available here:  http://www.cdcgroup.com/uploads/cdcstrategypresentation_20120531%5Bcompatibilitymode%5D%5B0%5D.pdf

result_comments: CDC's strategy document does not contain information on assistance to different countries and institutions for the next three years. It contains overview details of current portfolio value and 2016 projection of total portfolio value.

result_comments: Map shows location of investments in a central system, but not details. A list of investee businesses is published. More details are found in the annual reviews and case studies.  CDC publishes data about some (but not all) underlying portfolio companies in case studies.  The 'businesses we back' database allows you to search by country and sector, but it only lists the name of the business. It does not contain any other basic information, such as investment amounts, timeframes, or the fund that the business is part of.  There is other information on funds and businesses elsewhere on the site, but it is not easy to draw it all together, so we cannot consider the 'businesses we back' database to be comprehensive.
result_review: UK-CDC PeerReviewer: There is also a searchable database of all CDC's investments at this link here:  http://www.cdcgroup.com/businesses-we-back.aspx  Users can search by country, region or sector.

result_comments: CDC's strategy document provides a brief (1 slide) overivew of investment strategies for Africa and South Asia (pp15 and 17), but this is insufficient detail. For CDC, we could accept a fund strategy as equivalent to a country strategy, so the required level of detail would be the strategy behind a specific fund, not a continent or region as a whole.
result_review: UK-CDC PeerReviewer: CDC doesn't publish country strategy for each country it invests in, but the comment above 'no detailed published for activities in each country' is inaccurate.  A searchable database that will list all investments in each country exists here: http://www.cdcgroup.com/businesses-we-back.aspx   The 2012 strategy sets out the strategy for Africa and for Asia separately, as well as other themes. Although there is no separate regional strategy document, the overall strategy does contain the relevant sort of information that we might expect. JA

result_comments: On the FAQ page of the CDC website, CDC states:   Which financial instruments does CDC use?  Between 2004 and 2011 CDC invested primarily in private equity funds.  From 2011, CDC will increase its range of financial instruments to include the following in addition to intermediated equity:      Direct equity investments - will allow CDC to target businesses with high potential development impact; and     Debt investments - will allow CDC to target frontier markets where investment infrastructure is under-developed. A strategy to provide capital to financial institutions will be particularly helpful to small and medium size enterprises.  CDC therefore uses multiple instruments, which must be stated on a per-activity basis.

A strategy to provide capital to financial institutions will be particularly helpful to small and medium size enterprises.

UK-DFID PeerReviewer: DFID works directly with some recipient partner countries to hand over this information manually. In India DFID works through systems put in place by the Government of India so our funds flow through budget classifiers set out by them, ensuring our funding is integrated with the Government of India's budget.   In Malawi, the DFID office completes a monthly report on planned and actual disbursement figures all our programmes and sends to the Ministry of Finance, who enters the information into their aid management platform. The Ministry of Finance publishes an annual report on aid flows including donor performance on reporting. http://www.finance.gov.mw/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=110&Itemid=114  DFID is committed to providing this information in an automated way and will pilot this approach in 2012.

result_review: UN-UNDP PeerReviewer: UNDPâ€™s current Strategic Plan, its financial framework and relevant global and regional programmes were extended for an additional two years until 2013 by the UNDP Executive Board in its decision 2009/9. This decision also articulated the Executive Boardâ€™s expectation with regards to annual results reporting, such as increased results focus and reporting at outcome level.   The Strategic Plan outlines the major goals and objectives for UNDP, as approved by the Executive Board. The plan outlines the areas of focus for UNDP based on its mandate and comparative advantages, and signals the ways in which the organization works to enhance development effectiveness, including its focus on national ownership, national capacity development, gender equality and womenâ€™s empowerment as well as south-south cooperation.    In addition to the Strategic Plan, UNDP has also articulated an Action Plan, in 2010, outlining immediate to medium term priorities for the organization.   The current versions of UNDPâ€™s strategic documents are always publicly accessible at UNDPâ€™s website: http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/operations/executive_board/overview.html   UNDP should be rated â€œ4â€ on this question.    - The decision to update the 2008-2011 Strategic plan can be found on p. 9 here: http://web.undp.org/execbrd/pdf/dp2010-2e.pdf. Changed to a '4'- JA from Publish What You Fund

The UNDP programming arrangements (2008-2011, extended to 2013 along with the Strategic Plan) outline UNDPâ€™s resource allocation policy and procedure. It is publicly available on UNDPâ€™s website at http://www.undp.org/content/dam/undp/library/corporate/Executive%20Board/dp07-44.pdf.   At the UNDP Executive Board in February 2012, the 2008-2013 programming arrangements were reviewed: http://www.undp.org/content/dam/undp/library/corporate/Executive%20Board/2012/first-regular-session/english/dp2012-3e.pdf   - Changed to a 4 based on donor comments- JA from Publish

result_comments: Only to 2013.
result_review: UN-UNDP PeerReviewer: At the global level, UNDP publishes its biennial support budgets on its public website, the latest one being for 2012-2013. It is viewable at: http://www.undp.org/content/dam/undp/library/corporate/Executive%20Board/dp2011-34e.pdf   It is important to note that UNDP is not a donor, but a multilateral organization that is voluntarily funded by UN member states. Often, funds are allocated by donors not long ahead of time, for short time spans (1 year, 2 years) only, and they come heavily earmarked. More information on this issue is publicly available on the UNDP website in the document â€˜Status of regular funding commitments to the United Nations Development Programme and its associated funds and programmes for 2012 and onwardâ€™, which was published as part of the advance documentation for the 2012 Annual Session of the Executive Board (see http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/operations/executive_board/documents_for_sessions/adv2012-annual/)   Finally, UNDP publishes Country Programme Action Plans in every country it works in that provides forward planned budgets three to five years ahead (2011-2015) For example, see the Zambia Country Programme Action Plan here: http://204.200.211.80/joomla/attachments/279_UNDP Zambia CPAP 2011-2015.pdf   - While there are Country Action Plans for each country, this does not give a clear enough picture of UNDP's spending at the organisational level- therefore, I suggest a score of '1' as organisational level budgets to do not appear to exist on a three year basis (rather they are collected on the biennial basis mentioned above.) Changed to a '1' - JA from Publish

result_comments: Only to 2013
result_review: UN-UNDP PeerReviewer: UNDP works in a highly decentralized way, and each UNDP country office has its own three-to-five year country programmes (with budgets), which are aligned with the national development planning cycles of their individual host countries. In addition to allocations that they receive from UNDP headquarters, country offices mobilize funding locally.   It is a corporate requirement in UNDP in line with our Information Disclosure Policy that all UNDP country offices must publish their Country Programme Documents and their operational plans, called Country Programme Action Plans, online. All country office websites can be accessed through the global UNDP website.   As an example, we are providing a hyperlink to Zambiaâ€™s Country Programme Action Plan, which shows that the UNDP country office publishes its budget plan five years ahead (2011-2015). Of note, because of the way UNDP, and the UN system at country level, works, forecasts do not roll forward, but they are tied to the duration of the country programme.

result_comments: Also http://www.undp.org/content/dam/undp/library/corporate/Programme%20and%20Operations%20Policies%20and%20Procedures/contract_and_procurement_2012_04_27.pdf
Last audit was 2009, on a biennial basis
result_review: UN-UNDP PeerReviewer: The United Nations Board of Auditors reviews the financial report and audited financial statements of the UN funds and programmes including UNDP on biennial basis, the last one currently available publicly being the 2010 report of the Board of Auditors for the biennium ended 31 December 2009 (http://www.undp.org/content/dam/undp/documents/about/transparencydocs/UNBOA%20audit%20report%20A65_5_add_1%20for%20biennium%202008%20to%202009.pdf).  The report of the Board of Auditors for the biennium ended 31 December 2011 will only be presented to the UN General Assembly in September 2012, and then be made publicly available on the UNDP website.  UNDP is strongly committed to organizational transparency. The organization aims to disclose its internal audit reports by publishing them on its website, noting that confidentiality may have to be protected in certain circumstances. UNDP proposes a series of steps which, if approved by the Executive Board, will lead to public disclosure of internal audit reports by the end of 2012. In moving towards full disclosure, UNDP will ensure that (a) internal audit reports remain a central tool to  inform senior management in its decision-making; (b) proper diligence is exercised, to which end the quality assurance capacity and the recommendation follow-up processes of the internal audit office will be strengthened, as appropriate, to ensure the integrity and quality of the information disclosed; and (c) there are effective safeguards in place to maintain the confidentiality of any information deemed particularly sensitive. UNDP is pursuing this jointly with UNFPA and UNOPS.  Since the beginning of 2012, UNDP has been publishing on its public website a list of all internal audit reports issued: http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/operations/accountability/audit/internal_audits.html. As a result, what has been audited â€“ and which audit reports can be made available under the confidential disclosure procedures adopted by the Executive Board â€“ is now public knowledge. Member States may use this information to determine reports to which they wish to request confidential access, either on site or through the secure remote access system.   - Having a biennial schedule for audits, I have scored a '4' here. JA from Publish

result_review: UN-UNDP PeerReviewer: All UNDP country offices are publishing their forward planned budgets and documents for the next three to five years when they begin a new programming cycle, depending on the country context (in volatile contexts, the planning timeframe tends to be three years, whereas it is typically four to five years in stable contexts).   Please see, as an example, Zambia's Country Programme Action Plan, which shows that the UNDP Zambia country office publishes its budget plan five years ahead (2011-2015). Of note, because of the way UNDP, and the UN system at country level, works, forecasts do not roll forward, but they are tied to the duration of the country programme. As regards the comment on the resources being indicative, we believe that this will be the case for all development cooperation. Multi-year budgets are mostly planning figures to the best of the providers' intentions. However, forward planning budgets might change in occurrences such as the global financial crisis, etc.    - Changed to a 3 based on donor comments- JA from Publish

It is a corporate requirement in UNDP that units, which manage programmes and projects, formulate and publish a management response outlining  how they will address each single evaluation recommendation, and in which time frame.  All management responses are also made publicly available.     - Evaluation reports can be found here, and this database does appear to be comprehensive, changed to a 4. http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/operations/accountability/evaluation/overview.html - JA from Publish

To assess Freedom of Information Acts for bilateral donors, we are using the Right to Information Rating published by AccessInfo and the Center for Law and Democracy. The RTI Rating uses a 150-point scale, which we have broken down into a four-point scale:   1= No Freedom of Information Act  2= score of 1-60 on the RTI Rating  3= score of 61-90 on the RTI Rating  4= score of 91-150 on the RTI Rating   Donor scored an 89 on the 150 point scale
Assessed on 07/08/2012

Though DOD publishes several strategy documents (space strategy, cyber strategy etc.) many are classified.  2013 Budget Request may be admissible as an overall strategy document. - JA from Publish What You Fund
result_review: USA-Defense PeerReviewer: The key overarching Defense strategy document is the Quadrennial Defense Review, which is published every four years and sets the long-term course for DoD as it assesses the threats and challenges the US faces and re-balances DoD's strategies, capabilities, and forces to address today's conflicts and tomorrow's threats.  This document along with other related documents, may be found at http://www.defense.gov/qdr/

List of allocations cannot score a '4', would need a document that details how allocation priorities are decided, and the procedures necessary to go through such a decision. JA from Publish
result_review: USA-Defense PeerReviewer: It's not appropriate to judge DoD on this criteria given DoD does not provide foreign assistance, which is the purview of the U.S. Department of State (DoS).  DoD assists DoS with the implementation of certain military assistance accounts, but these accounts are ultimately appropriated to DoS who makes the decision regarding the use of such funds.  DoD does, however, conduct humanitarian assistance and disaster relief efforts, which are contingent upon circumstances.  As such, planning is not conducted in the traditional sense as performed by DoS or the U.S. Agency for International Development (i.e. longterm basis).  That said, there are DoD programs that provide corollary capacity building benefit during the conduct of U.S. missions, and these will be made public via www.foreignassistance.gov in the coming months.  However, Congress appropriates funding for these activities on a temporary annual basis given these activities are considered, as such.

result_comments: Both annual budget materials and the Future Years Defense Plan (FYDP) project budget assumptions for three to five years in the future. However, actual allocations depend on spending bills approved by Congress.
result_review: USA-Defense PeerReviewer: It may not be appropriate to judge USG on this criteria given Congress determines agency budgets on a yearly basis.  There are times when budgets are not agreed, and USG must operate under continuing resolutions.  As noted, DoD publishes both its annual budget and projected budget assumptions for 3-5 years into the future, so it is unclear how we might score higher on this criteria given conditions.

result_comments: Funding for aid related to overseas contingency operations (OCO account) is projected three years into the future, but funds from the Overseas Humanitarian Disaster Assistance and Human Aid account is largely allocated in response to unplanned disasters.
result_review: USA-Defense PeerReviewer: See answers to related questions 3 and 4.  It may not be appriopriate to judge DoD on this criteria.

result_comments: Tenders for sub-contracts are often not disclosed. Many tenders for overseas contracts are also not disclosed.
result_review: USA-Defense PeerReviewer: Note that this is another area difficult to judge or improve DoD performance given funds are paid to prime contractors, who may in turn have private contractural arrangements with other contractors to perform components of the work.  We are looking into the legal requirements requiring prime contractors to make public the sub-contrators that work for them given DoD contractural arrangments are only with the prime contractor.

result_comments: DOD has never passed an audit as required by law. The agency has pledged to make its financial systems audit-ready by 2017, but sub-agencies are progressing at varying speeds.

result_review: USA-Defense PeerReviewer: Agree that this is not applicable to DoD; see response to question #3.  This is more appropriate for the U.S. Department of State and U.S. Agency for International Development.  - Based on donor comments, changed to '1'- JA from Publish

result_comments: Though DOD does not publish country-specific strategies, many of the combatant commands publish strategy posture statements on their web sites.
result_review: USA-Defense PeerReviewer: DoD provides posture statements as noted to the maximum extend permissible for public release, and as applicable to its mission.  U.S. foreign policy country-strategies are the puriew of the Department of State, so it's not clear how DoD could improve its scoring on this indicator given circumstances, aside from acknowledging it provides information to maximum extent permissible. result_review: USA-MCC PeerReviewer: MCC publishes five year forward planning budgets at the outset of all five year compact agreements. result_review: USA-PEPFAR PeerReviewer:

result_evidence: PEPFAR funding is appropriated by the US government for one year at a time.

result_review: USA-PEPFAR PeerReviewer: PEPFAR funding is appropriated by the US government for one year at a time.

USA-PEPFAR PeerReviewer: We believe the score should be 4. The 'organization' is the US Government, as PEPFAR is an initiative rather than an agency; PEPFAR procurements are executed by its implementing US Government agencies, USAID and CDC. Each publishes its procurement procedures:   http://transition.usaid.gov/business/  http://www.cdc.gov/od/pgo/funding/grants/grantmain.shtm  - Changed to a 4 based on donor comments- JA from Publish

result_evidence: Some organizations that receive PEPFAR funding provide further details on individual tenders. This takes considerable searching with only a small chance of turning up results. These sites include: fbo.gov and grants.gov
result_review: USA-PEPFAR PeerReviewer: We believe the score should be 4. The 'organization' is the US Government, as PEPFAR is an initiative rather than an agency; PEPFAR procurements are executed by its implementing US Government agencies, USAID and CDC. Information on all tenders is available through the US government's grants.gov website, which serves as a central clearinghouse. While it is true that the site encompasses grants beyond PEPFAR, and requires the user to search to identify PEPFAR-specific information, that does not negate the reality that 'the organization publishes all tenders.'   - Changed to a 4 based on donor comments- JA from Publish

result_evidence: Audits of PEPFAR programs happen on an ad hoc basis and are conducted by different groups such as the Government Accountability Office and the Institute of Medicine. One example is: http://www.developmentwork.net/audit-database-project?sobi2Task=sobi2Details&catid=2&sobi2Id=182
result_review: USA-PEPFAR PeerReviewer: PEPFAR is independently audited by the Inspectors General of the implementing agencies and the Goverment Accountability Office.  These organizations choose the topics for their audits and evaluation, which are released on a rolling basis, and often more than once a year.   An example of a State Inspector General report can be found here. Other reports can be found by searching the websites of the relevant agency IGs: http://oig.state.gov/documents/organization/178166.pdf  The Government Accountability Office reports on PEPFAR can be found here: http://gao.gov/search?q=pepfar  In addition, as per the mandate of Congress, the Institute of Medicine is charged with performing a multiyear evaluation of PEPFAR. Information about this independent multi-year study can be found here: http://iom.edu/Activities/Global/PEPFAR2.aspx  All of these documents are publicly available on the websites of the evaluators, although PEPFAR, at this time, does not always link to these evaluations.     - Changed to a 3 based on donor comments- JA from Publish

result_comments: Does not have all activities in all countries.  To be more specific, all countries are listed, but the country pages do not have project data, only general information on the activities in each country. JA from Publish What You Fund.

result_comments: To assess Freedom of Information Acts for bilateral donors, we are using the Right to Information Rating published by AccessInfo and the Center for Law and Democracy. The RTI Rating uses a 150-point scale, which we have broken down into a four-point scale:   1= No Freedom of Information Act  2= score of 1-60 on the RTI Rating  3= score of 61-90 on the RTI Rating  4= score of 91-150 on the RTI Rating

result_review: WorldBank-IDA PeerReviewer: The scoring should be upgraded to 3.  Every country partnership strategy for an IDA only country has an annual forward allocation for that country for the duration of the CAS period whch is usually 4-5 years.  However, in cases of what are known as ' IDA-IBRD blend' countries (meaning that they are financed by both sources) indicating an annual forward allocation beyond the next fiscal year is more difficult as it depends on the market conditions and the resulting trade off between IDA and IBRD resources that the country can secure.    To get a more aggregate sense of the IDA replenishment process, please refer to: 'A Review of IDAâ€™s Long Term Financial Capacity and  Financial Instruments'. February 2010: http://siteresources.worldbank.org/IDA/Resources/Seminar%20PDFs/73449-1271341193277/IDA16-Long_Term_Financing.pdf

result_review: WorldBank-IDA PeerReviewer: This score for this question should be upgraded to 4. Instead of a Memorandum of Understanding, the World Bank produces and publishes a Country Assistance/Partnership Strategy for each country in collabaration with the government and after consullation with other stakeholders in the country. These documents are aligned with the country's medium term plans.  In addition, for every IDA or IBRD  financed program or project there is a legal agreement that constitutes the agreement between the two parties in the program.  These agreements are all published. result_review: WorldBank-IDA PeerReviewer: The score for this question should be upgraded to 4. This is because the World Bank publishes an Implementation Status and Results Report for each project, at least annually but often every 6 months. It also published an Implementation Completion Report at the end of the project as well as an indpendent evaluation of the project from IEG.    Moreover, the resercher's comments refer to the completeness of the information published.  The purpose of this question as it is phrased is not to assess the comprehensiveness of the information published in such documents, but to check whether they are publicly available.

WorldBank-IDA PeerReviewer: The World Bank publishes a description of all its projects on the project web page and in project documents including the Project Information document and the Project Appraisal document.   For instance, the Vishnugad Pipalkoti Hydro Electric Project has the following description:  'The objectives of the Vishnugad Pipalkoti Hydro Electric Project are: a) to increase the supply of electricity to India's national grid through the addition of renewable, low-carbon energy; and b) strengthen the institutional capacity of the borrower with respect to the preparation and implementation of economically, environmentally and socially sustainable hydropower projects. There are two components to the project. The first component is construction of the 444 MW Project in Chamoli district, Uttarakhand, India; and the second component is support to capacity-building and institutional strengthening at THDC India Limited, the developer of the Project'.

result_comments: It also follows the WB strategy, but this questions is difficlut to apply to the IFC as it is focus on investments and the private sector. It is not a donor as such.  The 'Road Map' 2013-15 appears to be the key strategic document at the organsational level for IFC.
result_review: WorldBank-IFC PeerReviewer: IFC follows the World Bank Group process for developing Country Assistance Strategies, which are driven by the member Countries. It also follows the World Bank's overarching strategic pillars. IFC does set its own strategy in terms of priority sectors and targets for investments. This is all spelled out in the IFC Road Map, which is published yearly. Here is the latest link:  http://www1.ifc.org/wps/wcm/connect/87c9800046b649beaa04abb254bfb7d4/Road+Map+FY13-15.pdf?MOD=AJPERES

result_comments: Again, it is difficult to reply to this quesiton. It is not a donor and depneds on the private sector applying for funding.   Nonetheless, the 'Road Map' lists several long-term and near-term strategic goals, and there may be policies and procedures to ensure that the private sector applications that are approved are in line with these goals. If such policies and procedures exist, they should be published.- JA at Publish What You Fund
result_review: WorldBank-IFC PeerReviewer: IFC does not have an 'aid allocation' budget, but does publish its budget and business plan every year, it also published targets in the Road Map, referred to earlier. I can't suggest a score, because the question does not really apply to IFC in the same sense as to a public institution.   http://www1.ifc.org/wps/wcm/connect/8068038046b64e10aa1eabb254bfb7d4/Business_Plan_BudgetFY2011.pdf?MOD=AJPERES   Agreed, for IFI's, who do not have an 'Aid Allocation' Policy, a document such as the FY11 Business Plan is equivalent. It should be noted that the key areas of the business plan to score for this question are on page 29 to 32. - JA from Publish What You Fund.

result_comments: this question does not apply. The IFC use its proftis to continue operating. It does not have a budget as if it were a donor.   This question should apply in that IFC conducts strategic planning based on projected figures, for example the 'Road Map' publishes planned expenditures based on projected/planned expenditures for FY2012. While its agreed that IFC could not publish a total budget, If the IFC produced projected figures for planned activities to 2015, it would score on this question. JA from Publish What You Fund.
result_review: WorldBank-IFC PeerReviewer: I agree with the answer, but the score should then be it does not exist. IFC does publish it's yearly budget as referred to before. http://www1.ifc.org/wps/wcm/connect/8068038046b64e10aa1eabb254bfb7d4/Business_Plan_BudgetFY2011.pdf?MOD=AJPERES

result_comments: See previous question. Decisions are made foliwing applications by the private sector. It uses its own funds and does not have a budget.  See response to previous question.- JA from Publish What You Fund.
result_review: WorldBank-IFC PeerReviewer: Again, I don't think the question really applies.

result_comments: In any case, this is for internal procument. Most of what the IFC does is investment in the private sectro (no procurement is done by the IFC).  http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/PROJECTS/PROCUREMENT/0,,pagePK:84271~theSitePK:84266,00.html

The IFC releases a lot of project information, but not audits. It invests in the private sector and therefore, audits conducted on the business partners are not disclosed. The IFC is controlled by the Independent Evaluation Group and it is also subject to internal audits.   Audited information begins on page 88 of IFC Financials, Projects, and Portfolio 2010 document. Appears to include all activities.- JA from Publish What You Fund

See previous question  Again, IFC theoretically has figures (projected or otherwise) for its activities in India, if these figures were published to 2015, IFC could score a '4'. JA from Publish What You Fund
result_review: WorldBank-IFC PeerReviewer: IFC makes investment decisions on a rolling basis. We do have targets and limits at the country level (published in the Road Map), but information about actual investments is published at the time of the investment, and for the life of the investment. I don't think the question applies the way we operate.

result_comments: Such a thing does not exists (see preivous quesiotns).  Yes such Memorandums do exist, see their mention in the article below. However, they are not published systematically. - JA from Publish What You Fund   http://www1.ifc.org/wps/wcm/connect/industry_ext_content/ifc_external_corporate_site/industries/financial+markets/news/ifc+addresses+development+challenges+in+south+asia?presentationtemplate=ifc_ext_design/AlternatePresentationTemplate
result_review: WorldBank-IFC PeerReviewer: We have a few 'MOUs' with institutions like the MasterCard Foundation. Otherwise, we have legal agreements (contracts) with clients, which cannot be published because they contain confidential information. We also have agreements with donors, which donors often disclose.

result_comments: There are impact evaluations, assesmentes, etc., but I am not sure about project evaluations as such.
result_review: WorldBank-IFC PeerReviewer: As indicated, we are publishing some impact evaluations currently. http://www1.ifc.org/wps/wcm/connect/Topics_Ext_Content/IFC_External_Corporate_Site/IDG_Home/Evaluating_Impact/  Agreed some evaluations are currently published, so we will upgrade to '3': http://www1.ifc.org/wps/wcm/connect/966b59804a957dcaae75fe9e0dc67fc6/IFC+China+Secured+Transactions+Evaluation+-+Final+Report+vf2.pdf?MOD=AJPERES. - JA from Publish What You Fund

result_review: WorldBank-IFC PeerReviewer: I agree with the comment. It doesn't apply to IFC.    - http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/spi.nsf/Content/Procurement states:   'Please note that IFC is involved only in the financing of projects, and has no part in the procurement process for any of these projects.  The local project company is responsible for all aspects of procurement, such as evaluation of bids and contract awards, and is the contact point for any information regarding the bidding process. The project company is identified in the Summary of Proposed Investment (SPI) for each project. '   PWYF guidelines say that 'We need an explicit statement from IFIs/private foundations that demonstrates their aid is not tied. This could, e.g. be in their procurement procedures. Some IFIs do tie their aid so this should be stated.'  I think the above note on IFC website captures the idea that there is no link between IFC providing finance and where the procurement must happen. Suggest a 4.  JA from Publish
